greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Distance from n-th highly composite number (cf. A002182) to nearest prime.
comment: a) Conjecture: entries > 1 will always be prime. The entry will be larger than the largest prime factor of the highly composite number.
b) Will 1 always be the most common entry?
c) While a prime may always be located close to each highly composite number, is the converse false?
d) Is there always a prime between successive highly composite numbers?

The second sentence of point (a) follows as both gcd(n, A151799(n)) = 1 and gcd(A151800(n), n) = 1 for all n > 2 and the fact that the highly composite numbers are products of primorials, A002110 (with the least coprime prime > the largest prime factor). See also the conjectures and notes in A129912 and A141345. (End)
link: Charles R Greathouse IV, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..19999
formula: a(1) = 1; for n > 1, a(n) = min(A141345(n), A324385(n)). - _Antti Karttunen_, Feb 26 2019
mathematica: With[{s = DivisorSigma[0, Range[Product[Prime@ i, {i, 8}]]]}, Map[If[PrimeQ@ #, 0, Min[# - NextPrime[#, -1], NextPrime[#] - #]] &@ FirstPosition[s, #][[1]] &, Union@ FoldList[Max, s]]] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Mar 11 2019 *)
xref: Sequences tied to conjecture a): A228943, A228945.
results.author: _Bill McEachen_, May 01 2006
